Location.LocationBody:
Online Games

We have some online games for your enjoyment. Here are the top five games on the site.  Most are Flash so play them while you can as Flash is dying across the internet these days. 

  1. Cubefield
  2. Learn To Fly
  3. Pigs Can Fly
  4. Shopping Cart Hero 2
  5. Achilles

 

Travel Pages

Check out our Travel Site for images of the places we've been!

Planet Source Code

If you came from Planet-Source-Code, thanks for dropping by.  However, I no longer have demo's hosted on this domain. 

 

This site runs on Web Project Mechanics my Open Source Content Management system at https://github.com/markhazleton/WebProjectMechanics

Location.LocationBody:
My busy life and lack of time to devote to the removal of excessive Guestbook spam has caused me to remove the Guestbook page from my site.    Seems like folks were more interested in hawking their own sites then commenting on my little corner of the web.   I'm looking into some ways to shore up my guestbook page to prevent the abuse, but still allow for an open discussion.  Check back in the next couple months.

In other news, many of my favorite clips on You Tube and Google Video have been pulled, seems like the copy right owner wants their fair share.  Can't say I blame them, but I will miss the content.

I continue to play with the new MS-Office suite. So far, I have to say that I like what I see. Not a ground breaking change, but a nice and welcomed evolution.   Have not braved the Vista world yet, but have a new laptop ready to try it out when I have the time and patience for the undertaking.

LocationTrail.Name: Home
LocationTrail.Description: The Frogsfolly Starting Point. From this page all things frogsfolly flow.

Location.LocationBody:
Well we made to the UK in one piece.  The last minute rounds of strep throat among the kids made the flight extra special.  (don't ask unless you are willing to buy several pints to get the whole story)
Our air shipment was waiting for us in the house and in the right rooms no less.  We bought a bed for Marlis at IKEA and drove it home ourself (see above for instructions on how to find out the details).
There is a great chip shop right down the street as well as some good Indian and Chineese take out.  We have even made it out for a brief visit to a castle ruin that is about 5 miles away.
I hope to have regular i-net access in a couple of weeks, until then email is difficult since I am on dial-up and my spam in my inbox increases by over 200 a day (argh!)

• Home
  • Site Blog
  • Arrival in the UK

Location.LocationDescription: In order to claim my rss feed for this site, I have to put an entry for Bloglines to read
Location.LocationBody:
Bloglines is a way to consolidate RSS feeds that I use. In order to claim that this web site is mine, I must create a page that shows up in the Web Site RSS Feed (frogsfolly.com/rss_menu.xml )  to say "This is Mine", so . . .

 "Hey Bloglines - This is me!"

Location.LocationBody: Digitized from a 1984 VHS tape. This is one of the famous Coffee Achievers tv spots, meant to encourage people to DRINK COFFEE. You can see how we here in the 21st Century have to laugh ourselves senseless at the idea that paid ads were necessary, and not even for a particular brand of coffee, just the product in general. Appearing in this ad: David Bowie (Jay Leno in 1985: "Come on! To David Bowie, a cup of coffee is merely a sedative at this point."), Kenny Anderson, Kurt Vonnegut, Ann Wilson and Nancy Wilson of the band Heart, and Cicely Tyson.

Location.LocationBody:
English Cuisine - Faggot and Peas

Faggots and Peas are an old English dish.  It is made from Pork (what part of the pig, I’m  not sure) and is covered in a dark brown gravy, it is usually served with peas here are some links to explain it all:  

  • The Faggot Family
  • The Good Faggot Guide
  • From the Guide to Black Country Cooking  
  • The Wikipedia takes a shot
    A faggot is a kind of meatball, a traditional dish in the UK, especially the southwest of England, Wales, and the Black Country. It is made from meat off-cuts and offal, especially pork. A faggot is traditionally made from pig heart, liver and fatty belly meat or bacon minced together, with herbs added for flavoring and sometimes breadcrumbs. The mixture is shaped in the hand into balls, wrapped round with caul (a membrane from the pig's abdomen), and baked. A similar dish, alm√¥ndega, is traditional in Portugal.
      

More English cuisine updates coming soon

Location.LocationDescription: This is my first day at Imagine Solutions
Location.LocationBody:
This is my first day at Imagine Solutions as a project manager.

Imagine Solutions is a software and services provider focused on improving business processes with digital imaging and enterprise content management (ECM) technologies. Through thier Distributed Capture platform, Conversions,and Professional Services, they help companies cut costs and drive efficiencies by decreasing their reliance on paper.

Location.LocationBody:
Monty Python Live at the Hollywood Bowl
We Were Poor (Four Yorkshiremen)

Yorkshireman I (Eric Idle):
Very passable, this, eh? Very passable.
All:
Ay, oh ay.
Yorkshireman II (Graham Chapman):
Nothing like a good glass of Chateau de Chasselet, eh, Josiah?
Yorkshireman III (Terry Jones):
Oh, you're right there, Obadiah.
Yorkshireman II:
Ay.
Yorkshireman I:
Who would have thought, thirty years ago, we'd all be sitting here drinking Chateau de Chaselet, eh?
All:
Ay, ay.
Yorkshireman IV (Michael Palin)
Them days we were glad to have the price of a cup of tea.
Yorkshireman II:
Ay! A cup of cold tea!
Yorkshireman IV:
Ay!
Yorkshireman I:
Without milk or sugar!
Yorkshireman III:
Or tea!
Yorkshireman IV:
In a cracked cup and all.
Yorkshireman I:
Oh, we never used to have a cup! We used to have to drink out of a rolled-up newspaper!
Yorkshireman II:
The best we could manage was to suck on a piece of damp cloth.
Yorkshireman III:
But you know, we were happy in those days, although we were poor.
Yorkshireman IV:
Because we were poor!
Yorkshireman III:
Ay!
Yorkshireman IV:
My old dad used to say to me: "Money doesn't bring you happiness, son!"
Yorkshireman I:
He was right!
Yorkshireman IV:
Ay!
Yorkshireman I:
I was happier then and I had nothing! We used to live in this tiny old house with great big holes in the roof.
Yorkshireman II:
House! You were lucky to live in a house! We used to live in one room, all twenty-six of us, no furniture, half the floor was missing, we were all huddled together in one corner for fear of falling.
Yorkshireman III:
You were lucky to have a room! We used to have to live in the corridor!
Yorkshireman IV:
Oh, we used to dream of living in a corridor! Would have been a palace to us! We used to live in an old water tank on a rubbish tip. We got woke up every morning by having a load of rotting fish dumped all over us! House, huh!
Yorkshireman I:
Well, when I say "house", it was just a hole in the ground, covered by a sheet of tarpaulin, but it was a house to us!
Yorkshireman II:
We were evicted from our hole in the ground. We had to go and live in a lake!
Yorkshireman III:
You were lucky to have a lake! There were 150 of us living in a shoebox in the middle of the road!
Yorkshireman IV:
A cardboard box?
Yorkshireman III:
Ay!
Yorkshireman IV:
You were lucky! We lived for three months in a paper bag in a septic tank! We used to have to get up at six in the morning and clean the paper bag, eat a crust of stale bread, go to work down the mill, fourteen hours a day, week in, week out, for sixpence a week, and when we got home, our dad would thrash us to sleep with his belt!
Yorkshireman II:
Luxury! We used to have to get out of the lake at six o'clock in the morning, clean the lake, eat a handful of hot gravel, work twenty hours a day at mill, for two pence a month, come home, and dad would thrash us to sleep with a broken bottle, if we were lucky!
Yorkshireman III:
Well, of course, we had it tough! We used to have to get up out of the shoebox at twelve o'clock at night, and lick the road clean with our tongues! Grab two bits of cold gravel, work twenty-four hours a day at mill for six pence every four years, and when we got home, our dad would slice us in two with a bread knife!
Yorkshireman I:
Right! I had to get up in the morning, at ten o'clock at night, half an hour before I went to bed, drink a cup of sulfuric acid, work twenty-nine hours a day down mill and pay mill-owner for permission to come to work, and when we got home, our dad and our mother would kill us and dance about on our graves, singing Hallelujah!
Yorkshireman IV:
Oh, ay. And you try and tell the young people of today that, and they won't believe you!
All:
No, no they won't!

Location.LocationDescription: Frogsfolly Debut on the world wide web
Location.LocationBody:
Frogsfolly Debuts on The World Wide Web

Christmas Present for Loving Wife of Mark Hazleton

12/25/1999 -- Today, in a generous gesture, Mark Hazleton has created this web page for his wife. The domain name was picked out by Lesley. The Frog's Folly was a favorite hangout of Mark and Lesley while they were dating. This started Lesley's life long interest in all things frog, including a special interest in Michigan J Frog of Warner Brothers fame.

By permission (thanks!), we were able to get a picture of the sign outside the bar.  The Folly is a great place to lose a few hours and throw back a swift half! We hope this web site will be the same.

Location.LocationName: More Customization of the Frogsfolly Template
Location.LocationTitle: More Customization of the Frogsfolly Template
Location.LocationDescription: Frogsfolly Now Has Customized YUI Menu
Location.LocationBody:
I have started to get under the hood of the Yahoo User Interface (YUI) menu functionality.  I have created a variation of the SAM skin for this site.  Since I have started to include the YUI framework in all of my site templates, I have been working on understanding how to customize the CSS when needed. I started by creating a test page on this site to explore how to best layout the site content.

So far, the menu seen on Frogsfolly has been modified to use more of the Frogsfolly Orange (also known as #FF9900).

Location.LocationDescription: Lesley, Mark and Marlis move to Poland to follow Lesley's job. General information about Poland.
Location.LocationBody:
Frogsfolly founders move to Poland

Lesley has accepted position in Lodz, Poland. Lesley, Marlis and Mark have moved to Poland are are living in a rented house. We have lots of room and welcome visitors.

Here is some information about Lodz and Poland:
 

Since the fall of Communism, Poland is on the move and growing fast in a free-market economy. It's a wheat farmer, a coal producer, a member of NATO and an increasingly popular skiing and hiking destination.

 

  • Weather in Lodz, Poland
  • If your European geography is as bad as mine, here is one map of Europe, and another.

Quick Facts and Figures

  • Official Name Republic of Poland
  • Capital City Warsaw
  • Climate Temperate with cold, moderately severe winters with frequent precipitation; mild summers with frequent showers and thundershowers
  • Latitude/Longitude 52? 00'N, 20? 00'E
  • Languages Polish (official)
  • Official Currency Zloty
  • Religions Catholic, others
  • Population 38,644,000
  • Land Area 304,460 sq km (117,552 sq miles)
  • Landforms Fronting the Baltic Sea, lowland plains cover most of the country with the Carpathian Mountains along the southern border with Slovakia
  • Land Divisions 16 provinces


Suggested Links

  • Poland web site here!

Yet another quiz to find our your profile.  This one is from the World66

Your travel type: Jet Set

A visit to a museum or an art gallery in the morning, an afternoon of shopping, dining out in a good restaurant and some drinks and a little party to end the day, the Jet Set traveller likes a full day.

Although he is quite active he is not the type to do any outdoor sports. When he has to walk a few blocks, he takes a cab. The Jet Set traveler is not much of a nature lover. "You mean the green stuff my parents have in their backyard?"

Location.LocationDescription: I found World66.com today, a wiki travel web site
Location.LocationBody:
I stumbled upon the site World66.com today.  World66 is taking the Wiki concept that works so well in the Wikipedia and applying it to travel.  This creates a travel guide with over 50,000 articles writen by folks just like you and me.  When reviewing a page, you can hit the edit button and update the content on the fly.  I added a new section on Boleslawiec which is a subset of what I have on my own Boleslawiec page.

One of the cool features of the site is that you can create Maps of where you hvae been in the world.  I have created my maps below.  -->

  • States in the USA
  • Places in the World

Location.LocationBody:
New Orleans - February 11, 1995

 

Family and friends joined the happy couple as the vows were exchanged at the beautiful St. Mary's Church in the "Uptown" section of New Orleans. After the ceremonies, the newlyweds kicked off a day of celebration at the Ladies Opera Guild Home in the beautiful "Garden District ". The food was prepared with excellence by Food Art of New Orleans.

The music was provided by a jazz combo that sounded a lot like Chet Baker. The couple danced to many songs, most special was their song "My Funny Valentine". Mark was heard saying, "This is the best thing that has ever happened to me." After the reception, the entire wedding party headed for the French Quarter to continue the celebration of this union.

Location.LocationDescription: Here is the Frogsfolly version of this famous New Orleans dessert which was invented by Ella Brennan, Chef Owner of the legendary New Orleans restaurant ‚ÄúThe Commander‚Äôs Palace.‚Äù
Location.LocationBody:
This is the Frogsfolly Bananas Foster as perfected on my back yard grill. It is really surprising how easy this dish is to prepare. It is also very rich and quite a show stopper. I like to prepare it on my backyard burner at night to highlight the flame.

Ingredients

  • 1 stick butter
  • 1/2 cup brown sugar
  • 4 bananas peeled and halved, cut lengthwise
  • 1/4 cup dark rum
  • 1/4 cup Triple Sec

Melt butter in a large skillet. Add brown sugar and stir together. Add the bananas and cook until caramelized over medium-high heat. Pour in the rum and liqueur and catch a flame off of the gas stove or a BBQ lighter. Let flame die down. Serve over vanilla ice cream.

• Home
  • Recipes
  • Bananas Foster

Location.LocationDescription: Chicken and Olives is a basic dish that I have been working on. I don't have it perfect just yet, let me know if you have any ideas.
Location.LocationBody:
Indegrediants

2 pounds boneless skinless chicken in strips
1 tablespoon olive oil

1 cup chopped onion
2 large garlic cloves, chopped
3 Vine Ripe Tomatoes
3/4 cup Kalamata olives or other brine-cured black olives, pitted, sliced
1/2 cup Garlic Wine Vinigar
2 teaspoons dried

2/3 cup crumbled feta cheese

Preparation

Sprinkle chicken with salt and pepper. Heat oil in large skillet over medium-high heat. Add chicken and sauté until brown, about 4 minutes per side. Transfer chicken to plate. Pour off all but 2 tablespoons drippings from skillet.

Add onion to drippings in skillet. Sauté over medium heat 3 minutes. Add garlic and stir until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add tomatoes with juices, olives, wine and oregano. Return chicken and any accumulated juices to sauce; bring to boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover and simmer until chicken is tender and cooked through, about 25 minutes.

Transfer chicken and sauce to platter. Sprinkle with feta cheese and serve.
Location.BreadCrumbHTML:
• Home
  • Recipes
  • Chicken and Olives

LocationTrail.Name: Chicken and Olives
LocationTrail.Description: Chicken and Olives is a basic dish that I have been working on. I don't have it perfect just yet, let me know if you have any ideas.

Location.LocationBody:
• 8 ounce Bread
    (stale bread is much easier to work with; bread should be coarse, country-style, not too dense: look for lots of holes within the bread, that kind will make a light crouton)
  • 1/4 pound, butter (1/2 cup)
  • 1/4 cup, olive oil
  • 4 cloves, garlic - peeled and minced
  • 6 shallots - peeled and minced
    (substitute 1/4 of one large sweet onion)
  • salt and pepper to taste
  • 4 teaspoons, dried thyme
  • 3 tablespoons, lemon juice
  • 1/3 cup, fresh chopped parsley
Preheat oven to 275 degrees.
Trim crusts from bread, and cut into one-inch cubes. Melt the butter in a deep skillet, along with the olive oil, and sauté` the garlic and shallots over low heat, until soft but not brown. Add salt, pepper and thyme to garlic and shallots as the mixture is sautéed. Then add lemon juice and chopped parsley, and blend well, continuing to cook briefly to incorporate flavors.

Remove the mixture from heat, and toss the bread cubes quickly and thoroughly in the mixture to coat the cubes evenly. Spread the bread cubes on a sheet pan, and bake at 275 degrees, tossing occasionally, until very crisp and lightly toasted. Drain finished bread cubes on a paper towel

Location.LocationBody:
Ginger Chicken

Preparation 45 mins plus at least 1 hour marinating time for Chicken and Pineapple

Serves: 6

Ingredients

  • 2lbs boneless skinless chicken (cut in large cubes)
  • 1 medium onion (chopped)
  • 1 Red Pepper (chopped)
  • Salt and freshly ground ground black pepper
  • Thinly sliced red pepper
  • Mangetout
  • Broccli
  • Carrots
  • Cubed Pineapple (drained if canned)

 

For the marinade:

  • 4 oz fresh root ginger, peeled, grated and squeezed for the juice
  • 2 tbsp finely chopped garlic
  • 1 cup Orange Juice
  • 1 cup soy sauce
  • 1 cup dry white wine

 

Directions

Prepare the marinade by mixing all ingredients in a container big enough to the chicken,pineapple and marinade. Marinate the pineapple and chicken for 1-4 hours.

Location.LocationBody:
Scalloped Potatoes with Ham

  • 1 pound fully cooked ham slice, 1/2-inch thick
  • 5 cup thinly sliced potatoes
  • 1 can (10 1/2 ounces) cream of mushroom soup or cream of celery soup
  • 1/4 cup milk
  • 1/2 cup chopped onion
  • 1/4 cup chopped green bell pepper
  • dash pepper
  • 2 tablespoons butter
  • 1 cup shredded Cheddar cheese, optional

Directions for scalloped potatoes
Cut ham in bite-size cubes. Place half of the potatoes in a greased, shallow, 2-quart baking dish. Cover with ham pieces. Top with remaining potatoes. Combine soup with milk, onion, green bell pepper, and ground black pepper; pour over potatoes. Dot with butter. Cover with foil and bake at 3500 for 1 hour. Remove covering; bake 30 to 45 minutes longer, or until potatoes are done. If desired, sprinkle shredded Cheddar cheese over the top of scalloped potatoes the last 15 minutes of baking time.
Scalloped potatoes serves 6.

Potatoes with Ham au Gratin

  • 4 cups diced potatoes
  • 2 cups chopped green onions
  • 5 tablespoons butter
  • 5 tablespoons all-purpose flour
  • 2 1/2 cups milk
  • 2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce
  • 1/2 teaspoon prepared yellow mustard
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • 1/2 teaspoon pepper
  • 1/4 teaspoon paprika
  • 4 pimiento, diced
  • 2 cups cheddar cheese, grated
  • 2 cups ham, cubed 1/2"
  • 1/2 cup plain bread crumbs
  • 4 tablespoons butter

In a saucepan cook potatoes and onions together in lightly salted water until tender, 12 - 15 minutes. Drain. To make white sauce melt butter in a medium saucepan. Add flour stirring until blended. Cook and slowly stir in milk. Add Worcestershire, mustard, salt, pepper, paprika and pimiento. Stir until thick. Place 1/2 of the cooked potatoes and onions in a large buttered 3-quart baking dish. Cover potatoes with 1/2 of the cheese. Spread all the ham on the cheese. Cover with remaining potatoes.

Pour white sauce over all. Sprinkle remaining cheese on top. Place bread crumbs on cheese. Dot top with butter. Bake in preheated 350 degree F oven until top is melted, about 10 minutes.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

Location.LocationDescription: Recipie for Jambalaya, a cajun favorite with Chicken and Sausage in a tomato and rice dish.
Location.LocationBody:
Jambalaya

"Cajun Classic"

Makes 6 to 8 servings


Prep Time:
Cook Time:
Ready in:

 

 

Ingredients 

4 Chicken Breasts

1 onion

1 stalk of celery

1.5 pounds of sausage (1/2 pound hot, 1 pound regular chappalhill garlic or pork and venison at Kroger )

4 onions chopped

4 cloves of garlic minced

1 red pepper diced (can use yellow or orange as well) Add = poblano pepper for a little zest

2 cans hunts diced tomatoes (roasted garlic or red pepper spiced are good)

3 cooking spoons oil

3 cooking spoons flour

2 cups of rice

6 to 7 cups of stock

 

 

Directions  
 

Chop one onion and celery stalk in large pieces and boil with chicken breasts for 1 hour. This makes the stock for use later and prepares the chicken for the jambalaya. Chop 4 onions, red pepper, garlic and slice sausage and sauti. Prepare the roux in large stockpot. Roux: Heat 3 cooking spoons of oil until hot then add 3 cooking spoons of flour. Stir constantly until dark brown (the color of milk chocolate). Immediately add onions, garlic, and sausage. Stir and cook for 3 minutes. Add diced tomatoes and stir. Add chunked chicken and stir. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add 5 cups chicken stock from boiling chicken breasts. Stir and add 2 cups of rice. Cook for 30 minutes (or until all liquid is absorbed) on low to simmer stirring occasionally to avoid sticking. Take off heat and put into large dish. Wait 30 minutes before serving, better reheated.

Serves 8 to 10.

Location.LocationDescription: The meatloaf & recipe, an amerian classic, with a spicy mustard twist.
Location.LocationBody:
Meatloaf

This is an easy tasty meatloaf.

Makes 6 to 8 servings


Prep Time: 20 Minutes
Cook Time: 1 Hour
Ready in: 1 Hour 30 Minutes
Ingredients (Loaf)
  • 2 cups of Bread Crumbs
  • 1 medium Onion (chopped)
  • 1 medium Red Pepper (chopped)
  • 2 Cloves Garlic (minced)
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 1/2 lbs Ground Veal (or pork)
  • 1 1/2 lbs Ground Beef (or lamb)
  • 2 Tablespoons Horseradish
  • 2 1/2 teaspoons salt
  • 1 teaspoon Dry Mustard
  • 1/4 cup Milk
  • 3/4 cup Ketchup
Ingredients (Sauce)
  • 3/4 cup Ketchup
  • 2 Tablespoons Brown Sugar
  • 2 Tablespoons Hot Mustard
  • 1 Tablespoon Dry Mustard
  • 1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce
Directions
  1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (~205 degrees C).
  2. Prepare bread crumbs, onions, and red pepper.
  3. In a large bowl, beat eggs slightly and mix in ground meat, bread crumbs, onions, and red peppers
  4. After mixture is well blended, ad horseradish, salt, dry mustard, milk and ketchup to bowl
  5. Lightly mix and shape into loaf
  6. Place loaf in a cooking dish (with space around loaf), indent the top of the loaf
  7. Mix all sauce ingredients together and coat the loaf. Use excess to fill the indentation in the top
  8. Bake in bottom rack of oven for 1 hour
Enjoy

LocationTrail.Name: Meatloaf
LocationTrail.Description: The meatloaf & recipe, an amerian classic, with a spicy mustard twist.

Location.LocationBody:
Ingredients
Directions
  • 1 lb lean ground beef
  • 1 lb ground lamb
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 cup milk
  • ½ cup rolled oats
  • ½ cup chopped parsley
  • 1 cup minced onion
  • ½ cup red pepper, minced
  • juice of ½ lemon
  • grated zest of ½ orange
  • 1 cup pine nuts
  • 1 cup white raisins
  • 1 tsp ground allspice
  • 1 tsp dried thyme
  • l½ tsp salt
  • 1 tsp black pepper
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 3 TBS Worcestershire sauce
  • 2 TBS clarified butter
  1. Preheat oven to 425°
  2. In a bowl, combine ground beef, and lamb. In a separate bowl, beat eggs, Stir in the milk and oats. Pour into the meats. Mix thoroughly.
  3. Add all other ingredients except clarified butter. Mix well. (use your hands).
  4. Shape mixture into an oval loaf and place in a roasting pan. Drizzle with clarified butter and bake for 1 hour. Serve drizzled with sauce.
Yield: six to eight servings.

Sauce

Ingredients Directions
  • 2 TBS butter (or olive oil)
  • 1 cup finely chopped onions
  • ½ cup finely chopped green pepper
  • 1 bay leaf
  • 1 clove garlic, minced
  • Juice of 1 lemon
  • ½ cup white raisins
  • 1 tsp dried thyme
  • 1 tsp ground allspice
  • 4 cups canned tomatoes, with their juice (use Italian with basil)
  • 2 TBS tomato paste (optional)
  • 3 TBS chopped parsley
  1. In a skillet, heat butter (olive oil). Add onions, green pepper, and bay leaf and sauté until the onion is translucent and limp, about 5-10 minutes.
  2. Add the remaining ingredients, except tomato paste and parsley, breaking the tomatoes into small pieces as you add them. Simmer for 30 minutes, or until sauce begins to thicken.
  3. Add the tomatoes paste and stir well. Cook 15 minutes. Add the parsley, stir well. Serve over the Meat Loaf.
Yield: 4 cups.

Location.LocationBody:
Ginger Salmon

"This is a recipe I came upon while in Poland.  I was doing a lot of the cooking and wanted to do something different.   

I got some fresh ginger and salmon and it took off from there. "

Makes 2 to 4 servings


Prep Time: 20 Minutes
Cook Time: 1 Hour
Ready in: 1 Hour 30 Minutes

Ingredients

Salmon Filet

 Ingredients (Sauce)
  • Fresh Ginger (pickled ginger can be used in a pinch)
  • Sweet Chili Sauce (many varietes to choose from, can be found in Asian section)
  • Orange Juice
  • Fresh Citrus (Orange or Tangerine)
  • Soy Sauce
Directions
  1. Mince the ginger by chopping very fine
  2. Juice the citrus and finely chop the pulp
  3. In a small sause pan, add the Orange Juice, Ginger, Soy Sauce and pulp from the fresh citrus.  Add sweet chili sauce to taste. Bring to a low boil and let it reduce.  Be carefull not to allow the mixture to boil over.  As it reduces it will become thicker.  Tastes often and adjust as necessary by adding more juice or soy sauce.
  4. Place salmon filet skin down on a cooking sheet, Strain the pulp from the sauce and put a thin layer over the salmon, you may also add a little butter to the salmon.  Optional is to slice an orange or lemon and place the slices on top of the salmon
  5. Place salmon filet in oven at 325 for 30 mins
  6. Remove salmon filet, slice and then drizzle sauce over filet

Server with rice and steamed vegatables and a nice wine.

Enjoy

Location.LocationBody:
Pork With Ginger

Preparation 25 mins plus at least 30 mins marinating

Serves: 4

Calories/Fat: 254 cals / 13g

Sodium/Added sugar: 1.2g / none

Directions

Marinade the pork steaks in a non-metallic bowl with the ginger juice, soy sauce and white wine for at least 30 mins.

Heat 1 tbsp of oil in a frying pan and stir-fry the onion/red pepper for 4-5 mins or until softened. Set aside.

Heat the remaining oil in the same frying pan and fry the pork steaks for 6 mins, turning occasionally. Add the marinade and fry for a further 1 min.

Remove the pork steaks and add back in the onions and red pepper, reduce until you have a nice thick sause

Create a bed of rice and place the pork steak in the middle.

Drizzle the sauce over and arround the pork steak

Serve with Fresh Orange pieces and green beens

Location.LocationBody:
Spicy Crawfish Etouffee

"Another Cajun Classic"

Makes 6 to 8 servings


Prep Time:
Cook Time:
Ready in:

 

 

Ingredients  

2 tablespoons reduced-fat margarine

1 1/2 cups finely chopped onions

1/2 cup finely chopped green bell pepper (I use red peppers)

1/2 cup finely chopped celery

1 teaspoon salt

1 1/4 teaspoons ground red pepper

1 teaspoon paprika

1/4 teaspoon ground oregano

1/8 teaspoon ground thyme

1/8 teaspoon dried basil leaves, crushed

1/2, 6 ounce can condensed tomato paste

1 1/2 cups seafood stock or water (I use clam liquor - you can buy in jar in grocery store)

1 pound crawfish tails, peeled and deveined (I use frozen tails you can buy at store)

1/4 cup finely chopped green onions

2 tablespoons very finely chopped fresh parsley

2 cups hot cooked rice

 

 

Directions  

In a medium saucepan over high heat, melt the margarine.  Add the onions, bell pepper and celery; sauti stirring occasionally for 10 minutes.  Add the salt, pepper, paprika, oregano, thyme, and basil leaves, and cook for 5 minutes, stirring often.

Dissolve the tomato paste in the stock and add to the sauce pan.

Simmer for 10 minutes.  Stir in the crawfish, green onions and parsley.  Reduce the heat; cover and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring often.  Remove from the heat and let stand, covered, for 5 minutes before serving.  Serve over hot rice.

Instructions:
Left & Right Arrow keys: Control Flight
Spacebar: Use Rockets

Click Upgrades to buy them: If you have enough money.
The Game might seam like your not going far at first but don"t forget you need to buy upgrades to start really flying!

Description:
One Penguin Takes it personally when he is surfing the web and stumbles upon a web site telling him that he cant fly, after that he sets his mind to research and practice flying until he can prove the world that he can.. Learn to Fly!

Tips:

Location.LocationBody:
The phrase "when pigs fly" is an adynaton – a figure of speech so hyperbolic that it describes an impossibility. The implication of such a phrase is that the circumstances in question (the adynaton, and the circumstances to which the adynaton are being applied) will never occur.

The phrase is thought to come from an old Scottish proverb of the 16th century.

Pigs Can Fly is a unique puzzle game! Get the pig to the potion in 25 neat levels. But there is a fun twist - you need to use multiple cursors in order to beat each level. Give it a try!

Game Controls

Each colored potion resets the level and allows you to control a cursor. The pig can only be dragged with the pink cursor, and blue and green boxes can only be dragged with the blue and green cursors respectively. The objective is to get the pig to the potion so he can grow wings and fly away. In some levels, you are not even given a pink potion! The levels get more challenging so try to think it through first!

Location.LocationBody:
In Greek mythology, Achilles (also Akhilleus or Achilleus; Ancient Greek: ·ºàœáŒπŒªŒªŒµœçœÇ) was a Greek hero of the Trojan War, the central character and the greatest warrior of Homer's Iliad, which takes for its theme the Wrath of Achilles.

Achilles also has the attributes of being the most handsome of the heroes assembled against Troy,[1] as well as the best.

Later legends (beginning with a poem by Statius in the first century AD) state that Achillies was invulnerable in all of his body except for his heel. These legends state that Achilles was killed in battle by an arrow to the heel, and so an "Achilles' heel" has come to mean a person's principal weakness.

Bubble Tanks Tower Defense by Hero Interactive, LLC
Evolve your towers for epic win.

Bubble Tanks Tower Defense takes Hero's popular series into new genres and beyond! With 7 enemy types, over 11 unique tower paths, tower merging allowing for mega towers and mega-mega towers (the size of 16 towers combined!), and 52 whopping game modes, we're pretty sure you'll have plenty to keep you busy until the release of Bubble Tanks Arenas. :) If that's not enough for you, just check the "FML" checkbox from level select and prepare to get your world rocked... er... blocked.


Publisher's Note:

When looking for a good example of a map mash-up, my first thoughts were real estate and business yellow pages.  This is until I found MappyHour !  A site than any drinking consultant would love to land on.  Combining the need for consultants to find a place to wash down a few pints with the Google mapping engine is pure genius.  Let's hope it takes off.

Location.LocationBody:
What is Flickr?

Flickr is an image and video hosting website, web services suite, and online community platform. It was one of the earliest Web 2.0 applications. In addition to being a popular Web site for users to share personal photographs, the service is widely used by bloggers as a photo repository. The popularity of flickr has been fueled by its organization tools, which allow photos to be tagged and browsed by keyword, much like any search engine.

Flickr is owned by Yahoo!

On this page you will see news about Flickr and some examples of the types of feeds you can get using the public Flickr RSS feeds.
Location.LocationSummary: What is Flickr?

Location.LocationBody:
StumbleUpon - Social Bookmarking

StumbleUpon is a social bookmarking site that allows you save your favorite sites, plus stumble through other bookmarks by category.

There is a nice toolbar for your browser (works best in FireFox).  You can get feeds for your favorites so you can pull them into your RSS reader or website.
Location.LocationSummary: StubleUpon is a social bookmarking site that allows you save your favorite sites, plus stumble through other bookmarks by category.

Location.LocationBody:
What is Twitter?

Twitter the site is a micro-blogging social media web site.  Think of it like group texting with a limit of 140 characters.  What people do with twitter is varied. Some use it as a social bookmarking site, the post a short comment and a shortened URL, others use it as a way to update there community with a status of what they are doing.

Twitter search allows you to do a keyword search on all updates across the site.

Twitter the company is a privately funded start up with offices in the SoMA neighborhood of San Francisco, CA. Started as a side project in March of 2006, Twitter has grown into a real-time short messaging service that works over multiple networks and devices.

 

Kevin explains Twitter to Dave

Location.LocationBody:
I have started using the Yahoo! User Interface(YUI) library CSS on my sites. I have found that some combinations do not alway render the way I"d like on IE and Firefox. So I have created this page to test some combinations, and to use as a reference when building new pages. Here is the description of the YUI library from Yahoo!:

The Yahoo! User Interface (YUI) Library is a set of utilities and controls, written in JavaScript, for building richly interactive web applications using techniques such as DOM scripting, DHTML and AJAX. The YUI Library also includes several core CSS resources. All components in the YUI Library have been released as open source under a BSD license and are free for all uses.

 

Now on to the samples

Four Colums by using nested yui-g

<div style="background-color: orange;" class="yui-g">
  <div style="background-color: black;" class="yui-g first">
    <div style="background-color: red;" class="yui-u first">ONE</div>
    <div style="background-color: yellow;" class="yui-u">TWO</div>
  </div>
  <div style="background-color: black;" class="yui-g">
    <div style="background-color: green;" class="yui-u first">THREE</div>
    <div style="background-color: blue;" class="yui-u">FOUR</div>
  </div>
</div>
ONE
TWO
THREE
FOUR

Three Colums by using yui-gd (1/3-2/3) and yui-g(1/2 - 1/2)

<div style="background-color: green;" class="yui-gd">
  <div style="background-color: purple;" class="yui-u first">ONE</div>
  <div style="background-color: orange;" class="yui-g">
    <div style="background-color: yellow;" class="yui-u first">TWO</div>
    <div style="background-color: purple;" class="yui-u">THREE</div>
  </div>
</div>
ONE
TWO
THREE

Three Equal Columns Using YUI-GB

<div style="background-color: orange;" class="yui-gb">
   <div style="background-color: red;" class="yui-u first">ONE</div>
   <div style="background-color: yellow;" class="yui-u first">TWO</div>
   <div style="background-color: green;" class="yui-u">THREE</div>
</div>
ONE
TWO
THREE

Three Columns 2 Rail one Main Using GF and nested G

<div class="yui-gf" style="background-color: orange;">
  <div class="yui-u first" style="background-color: red;">ONE</div>
  <div class="yui-u" style="background-color: yellow;">
    <div class="yui-g" style="background-color: orange;">
      <div class="yui-u first" style="background-color: yellow;">TWO</div>
      <div class="yui-u" style="background-color: purple;">THREE</div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>


 
ONE
TWO
THREE

RIP to Flash. . .

There is now an HTML5 version --> HTML Cubefield

Navigate your way through a virtual world of cubes in this addictive game

Cubfield Description

CubeField Game where you navigate your way through a virtual world of cubes. This is an addictive flash game called Cubefield that once you start playing you can not stop. Can't wait for Cubefield 2. There is no reason to hack Cubefield or look for Cubefield 2 the game is simplicity at it's best. The Cubefield ability game replicates many of the brain games used by pilots to test reflexes.

Thank You Yo! Arcade

Article.ArticleBody: Well, we just finished a day of packing the house in Geneva.   We have most of the goods for our new Lake house packed and ready to go, lots and lots of boxes everywhere.
Article.ArticleSummary: Well, we just finished a day of packing the house in Geneva.

Article.ArticleBody:
Our Soon to be Home, here is some links and information . . .

Local History (thanks to www.balsallcom.com )

The Balsall Common Lions Club

A Map of the Area

The Knowhere Balsall Common Pages

Fine Eats at the Bengal Brasserie

Wikipedia on Birmingham

My busy life and lack of time to devote to the removal of excessive Guestbook spam has caused me to remove the Guestbook page from my site.    Seems like folks were more interested in hawking their own sites then commenting on my little corner of the web.   I'm looking into some ways to shore up my guestbook page to prevent the abuse, but still allow for an open discussion.  Check back in the next couple months.

In other news, many of my favorite clips on You Tube and Google Video have been pulled, seems like the copy right owner wants their fair share.  Can't say I blame them, but I will miss the content.

I continue to play with the new MS-Office suite. So far, I have to say that I like what I see. Not a ground breaking change, but a nice and welcomed evolution.   Have not braved the Vista world yet, but have a new laptop ready to try it out when I have the time and patience for the undertaking.
Article.ArticleSummary: My busy life and lack of time to devote to the removal of excessive Guestbook spam has caused me to remove the Guestbook page from my site.    Seems like folks were more interested in hawking their own sites then commenting on my little corner of the web.   I'm looking into some ways to shore up my guestbook page to prevent the abuse, but still allow for an open discussion.  Check back in the next couple months.

Article.ArticleBody:
Well we made to the UK in one piece.  The last minute rounds of strep throat among the kids made the flight extra special.  (don't ask unless you are willing to buy several pints to get the whole story)
Our air shipment was waiting for us in the house and in the right rooms no less.  We bought a bed for Marlis at IKEA and drove it home ourself (see above for instructions on how to find out the details).
There is a great chip shop right down the street as well as some good Indian and Chineese take out.  We have even made it out for a brief visit to a castle ruin that is about 5 miles away.
I hope to have regular i-net access in a couple of weeks, until then email is difficult since I am on dial-up and my spam in my inbox increases by over 200 a day (argh!)

Bloglines is a way to consolidate RSS feeds that I use. In order to claim that this web site is mine, I must create a page that shows up in the Web Site RSS Feed (frogsfolly.com/rss_menu.xml )  to say "This is Mine", so . . .

 "Hey Bloglines - This is me!"
Article.ArticleDescription: In order to claim my rss feed for this site, I have to put an entry for Bloglines to read

Article.ArticleBody: Well we have reached the end of 2004.  What a year it has been!
Article.ArticleDescription: Time to close the book on 2004. I have uploaded all of the December events to the site.

Article.ArticleBody: Digitized from a 1984 VHS tape. This is one of the famous Coffee Achievers tv spots, meant to encourage people to DRINK COFFEE. You can see how we here in the 21st Century have to laugh ourselves senseless at the idea that paid ads were necessary, and not even for a particular brand of coffee, just the product in general. Appearing in this ad: David Bowie (Jay Leno in 1985: "Come on! To David Bowie, a cup of coffee is merely a sedative at this point."), Kenny Anderson, Kurt Vonnegut, Ann Wilson and Nancy Wilson of the band Heart, and Cicely Tyson.

After a year in England, the Hazletons are on the move again.  We will be moving back to the US in July.  We are looking forward to seeing all our friends state-side, but we will miss the friends we have made in England.

Keep tuned for more information!

English Cuisine - Faggot and Peas

Faggots and Peas are an old English dish.  It is made from Pork (what part of the pig, I’m  not sure) and is covered in a dark brown gravy, it is usually served with peas here are some links to explain it all:  

  • The Faggot Family
  • The Good Faggot Guide
  • From the Guide to Black Country Cooking  
  • The Wikipedia takes a shot
    A faggot is a kind of meatball, a traditional dish in the UK, especially the southwest of England, Wales, and the Black Country. It is made from meat off-cuts and offal, especially pork. A faggot is traditionally made from pig heart, liver and fatty belly meat or bacon minced together, with herbs added for flavoring and sometimes breadcrumbs. The mixture is shaped in the hand into balls, wrapped round with caul (a membrane from the pig's abdomen), and baked. A similar dish, alm√¥ndega, is traditional in Portugal.
      

More English cuisine updates coming soon

This is my first day at Imagine Solutions as a project manager.

Imagine Solutions is a software and services provider focused on improving business processes with digital imaging and enterprise content management (ECM) technologies. Through thier Distributed Capture platform, Conversions,and Professional Services, they help companies cut costs and drive efficiencies by decreasing their reliance on paper.
Article.ArticleDescription: This is my first day at Imagine Solutions

Article.ArticleBody:
Monty Python Live at the Hollywood Bowl
We Were Poor (Four Yorkshiremen)

Yorkshireman I (Eric Idle):
Very passable, this, eh? Very passable.
All:
Ay, oh ay.
Yorkshireman II (Graham Chapman):
Nothing like a good glass of Chateau de Chasselet, eh, Josiah?
Yorkshireman III (Terry Jones):
Oh, you're right there, Obadiah.
Yorkshireman II:
Ay.
Yorkshireman I:
Who would have thought, thirty years ago, we'd all be sitting here drinking Chateau de Chaselet, eh?
All:
Ay, ay.
Yorkshireman IV (Michael Palin)
Them days we were glad to have the price of a cup of tea.
Yorkshireman II:
Ay! A cup of cold tea!
Yorkshireman IV:
Ay!
Yorkshireman I:
Without milk or sugar!
Yorkshireman III:
Or tea!
Yorkshireman IV:
In a cracked cup and all.
Yorkshireman I:
Oh, we never used to have a cup! We used to have to drink out of a rolled-up newspaper!
Yorkshireman II:
The best we could manage was to suck on a piece of damp cloth.
Yorkshireman III:
But you know, we were happy in those days, although we were poor.
Yorkshireman IV:
Because we were poor!
Yorkshireman III:
Ay!
Yorkshireman IV:
My old dad used to say to me: "Money doesn't bring you happiness, son!"
Yorkshireman I:
He was right!
Yorkshireman IV:
Ay!
Yorkshireman I:
I was happier then and I had nothing! We used to live in this tiny old house with great big holes in the roof.
Yorkshireman II:
House! You were lucky to live in a house! We used to live in one room, all twenty-six of us, no furniture, half the floor was missing, we were all huddled together in one corner for fear of falling.
Yorkshireman III:
You were lucky to have a room! We used to have to live in the corridor!
Yorkshireman IV:
Oh, we used to dream of living in a corridor! Would have been a palace to us! We used to live in an old water tank on a rubbish tip. We got woke up every morning by having a load of rotting fish dumped all over us! House, huh!
Yorkshireman I:
Well, when I say "house", it was just a hole in the ground, covered by a sheet of tarpaulin, but it was a house to us!
Yorkshireman II:
We were evicted from our hole in the ground. We had to go and live in a lake!
Yorkshireman III:
You were lucky to have a lake! There were 150 of us living in a shoebox in the middle of the road!
Yorkshireman IV:
A cardboard box?
Yorkshireman III:
Ay!
Yorkshireman IV:
You were lucky! We lived for three months in a paper bag in a septic tank! We used to have to get up at six in the morning and clean the paper bag, eat a crust of stale bread, go to work down the mill, fourteen hours a day, week in, week out, for sixpence a week, and when we got home, our dad would thrash us to sleep with his belt!
Yorkshireman II:
Luxury! We used to have to get out of the lake at six o'clock in the morning, clean the lake, eat a handful of hot gravel, work twenty hours a day at mill, for two pence a month, come home, and dad would thrash us to sleep with a broken bottle, if we were lucky!
Yorkshireman III:
Well, of course, we had it tough! We used to have to get up out of the shoebox at twelve o'clock at night, and lick the road clean with our tongues! Grab two bits of cold gravel, work twenty-four hours a day at mill for six pence every four years, and when we got home, our dad would slice us in two with a bread knife!
Yorkshireman I:
Right! I had to get up in the morning, at ten o'clock at night, half an hour before I went to bed, drink a cup of sulfuric acid, work twenty-nine hours a day down mill and pay mill-owner for permission to come to work, and when we got home, our dad and our mother would kill us and dance about on our graves, singing Hallelujah!
Yorkshireman IV:
Oh, ay. And you try and tell the young people of today that, and they won't believe you!
All:
No, no they won't!

Frogsfolly Debuts on The World Wide Web

Christmas Present for Loving Wife of Mark Hazleton

12/25/1999 -- Today, in a generous gesture, Mark Hazleton has created this web page for his wife. The domain name was picked out by Lesley. The Frog's Folly was a favorite hangout of Mark and Lesley while they were dating. This started Lesley's life long interest in all things frog, including a special interest in Michigan J Frog of Warner Brothers fame.

By permission (thanks!), we were able to get a picture of the sign outside the bar.  The Folly is a great place to lose a few hours and throw back a swift half! We hope this web site will be the same.
Article.ArticleDescription: Frogsfolly Debut on the world wide web

Article.ArticleBody: The web has a never ending array of funny vidoes.  This is one small sample ...

George Bush singing "Sunday Bloody Sunday"


While taking a random walk on the web, I found this video.  Great to see that W is a big fan of Bono.
Article.ArticleDescription: George Bush Covers U2 Great W Mix of U2

Article.ArticleBody: We are alive and well in the UK.  We have all our goods and I hoping to get broadband in the next couple weeks.  Lesley is working like a mad-woman but enjoying the process.  Marlis, Ian and Berit are all doing fine.

Well, I have 'sold' out and added Google Ads to Frogsfolly.com.

I have also started to recreate my old Search page.  I used to have a page with forms to enter text on LOTS of search engines.  I will be working on the new version here

Google has now released a page creator for the web. I have created my own Google Page using the page creator tool, just to give it a kick of the tires.  I wonder how well the google pages score on the goole index?
Here is some fun with an iPhone, new features!
I just saw this clip with Jon Stewart on Crossfire.  Thought it was interesting to say the least.
This is my last official day with Imagine Solutions.
Article.ArticleDescription: My last day with Imagine Solution

Article.ArticleBody: We took a long weekend to go out and see some sites. Amoung are travels were a vist to Goodrich Castle and the Roman city of Wroxeter. We stayed at a very nice, (yet hard to find in the dark) farm house just a little south of Ludlow.

Monty Python Live at the Hollywood Bowl
We Were Poor (Four Yorkshiremen)

Yorkshireman I (Eric Idle):
Very passable, this, eh? Very passable.
All:
Ay, oh ay.
Yorkshireman II (Graham Chapman):
Nothing like a good glass of Chateau de Chasselet, eh, Josiah?
Yorkshireman III (Terry Jones):
Oh, you're right there, Obadiah.
Yorkshireman II:
Ay.
Yorkshireman I:
Who would have thought, thirty years ago, we'd all be sitting here drinking Chateau de Chaselet, eh?
All:
Ay, ay.
Yorkshireman IV (Michael Palin)
Them days we were glad to have the price of a cup of tea.
Yorkshireman II:
Ay! A cup of cold tea!
Yorkshireman IV:
Ay!
Yorkshireman I:
Without milk or sugar!
Yorkshireman III:
Or tea!
Yorkshireman IV:
In a cracked cup and all.
Yorkshireman I:
Oh, we never used to have a cup! We used to have to drink out of a rolled-up newspaper!
Yorkshireman II:
The best we could manage was to suck on a piece of damp cloth.
Yorkshireman III:
But you know, we were happy in those days, although we were poor.
Yorkshireman IV:
Because we were poor!
Yorkshireman III:
Ay!
Yorkshireman IV:
My old dad used to say to me: "Money doesn't bring you happiness, son!"
Yorkshireman I:
He was right!
Yorkshireman IV:
Ay!
Yorkshireman I:
I was happier then and I had nothing! We used to live in this tiny old house with great big holes in the roof.
Yorkshireman II:
House! You were lucky to live in a house! We used to live in one room, all twenty-six of us, no furniture, half the floor was missing, we were all huddled together in one corner for fear of falling.
Yorkshireman III:
You were lucky to have a room! We used to have to live in the corridor!
Yorkshireman IV:
Oh, we used to dream of living in a corridor! Would have been a palace to us! We used to live in an old water tank on a rubbish tip. We got woke up every morning by having a load of rotting fish dumped all over us! House, huh!
Yorkshireman I:
Well, when I say "house", it was just a hole in the ground, covered by a sheet of tarpaulin, but it was a house to us!
Yorkshireman II:
We were evicted from our hole in the ground. We had to go and live in a lake!
Yorkshireman III:
You were lucky to have a lake! There were 150 of us living in a shoebox in the middle of the road!
Yorkshireman IV:
A cardboard box?
Yorkshireman III:
Ay!
Yorkshireman IV:
You were lucky! We lived for three months in a paper bag in a septic tank! We used to have to get up at six in the morning and clean the paper bag, eat a crust of stale bread, go to work down the mill, fourteen hours a day, week in, week out, for sixpence a week, and when we got home, our dad would thrash us to sleep with his belt!
Yorkshireman II:
Luxury! We used to have to get out of the lake at six o'clock in the morning, clean the lake, eat a handful of hot gravel, work twenty hours a day at mill, for two pence a month, come home, and dad would thrash us to sleep with a broken bottle, if we were lucky!
Yorkshireman III:
Well, of course, we had it tough! We used to have to get up out of the shoebox at twelve o'clock at night, and lick the road clean with our tongues! Grab two bits of cold gravel, work twenty-four hours a day at mill for six pence every four years, and when we got home, our dad would slice us in two with a bread knife!
Yorkshireman I:
Right! I had to get up in the morning, at ten o'clock at night, half an hour before I went to bed, drink a cup of sulfuric acid, work twenty-nine hours a day down mill and pay mill-owner for permission to come to work, and when we got home, our dad and our mother would kill us and dance about on our graves, singing Hallelujah!
Yorkshireman IV:
Oh, ay. And you try and tell the young people of today that, and they won't believe you!
All:
No, no they won't!

I have started to get under the hood of the Yahoo User Interface (YUI) menu functionality.  I have created a variation of the SAM skin for this site.  Since I have started to include the YUI framework in all of my site templates, I have been working on understanding how to customize the CSS when needed. I started by creating a test page on this site to explore how to best layout the site content.

So far, the menu seen on Frogsfolly has been modified to use more of the Frogsfolly Orange (also known as #FF9900).

Article.ArticleBody:
Frogsfolly founders move to Poland

Lesley has accepted position in Lodz, Poland. Lesley, Marlis and Mark have moved to Poland are are living in a rented house. We have lots of room and welcome visitors.

Here is some information about Lodz and Poland:
 

Since the fall of Communism, Poland is on the move and growing fast in a free-market economy. It's a wheat farmer, a coal producer, a member of NATO and an increasingly popular skiing and hiking destination.

 

  • Weather in Lodz, Poland
  • If your European geography is as bad as mine, here is one map of Europe, and another.

Quick Facts and Figures

  • Official Name Republic of Poland
  • Capital City Warsaw
  • Climate Temperate with cold, moderately severe winters with frequent precipitation; mild summers with frequent showers and thundershowers
  • Latitude/Longitude 52? 00'N, 20? 00'E
  • Languages Polish (official)
  • Official Currency Zloty
  • Religions Catholic, others
  • Population 38,644,000
  • Land Area 304,460 sq km (117,552 sq miles)
  • Landforms Fronting the Baltic Sea, lowland plains cover most of the country with the Carpathian Mountains along the southern border with Slovakia
  • Land Divisions 16 provinces


Suggested Links

  • Poland web site here!
  • Poland Information Page here!
  • Weather in Warsaw here!

Yet another quiz to find our your profile.  This one is from the World66

Your travel type: Jet Set

A visit to a museum or an art gallery in the morning, an afternoon of shopping, dining out in a good restaurant and some drinks and a little party to end the day, the Jet Set traveller likes a full day.

Although he is quite active he is not the type to do any outdoor sports. When he has to walk a few blocks, he takes a cab. The Jet Set traveler is not much of a nature lover. "You mean the green stuff my parents have in their backyard?"

top destinations:

Venice
Tokyo

stay away from:

Ciudad Perdida

I am trying out a new look for Frogsfolly.com.  I am moving towards a 100% CSS driven site.  I have been getting rid of all of the many offending tags in my scripts and templates.   I have been inpsired by the CSS Zen Garden.

Leave a note in the Guestbook and let me know what you think.   Or better still try out the Discussions

In more other changes, you can now register on ths site without sending me an email.  Just register and then send me a message via the site to let me know that you'd like to see the family pictures.

Well, the family is on the move again, this time we are heading out for Birmingham, England.  We are all excited about this new chapter in our lives, although we will miss our friends we have made in and arround Chicago these past 6 months.

I really enjoy listening to Pandora Internet Radio when I get a chance.  They have a great tool for picking out the songs based on a seed song or artist.  I have created a few stations to match moods.  Here I thought Pandora was just a chick with a box you don't want to open. 


Give it a try. Follow this URL

Article.ArticleBody:
I stumbled upon the site World66.com today.  World66 is taking the Wiki concept that works so well in the Wikipedia and applying it to travel.  This creates a travel guide with over 50,000 articles writen by folks just like you and me.  When reviewing a page, you can hit the edit button and update the content on the fly.  I added a new section on Boleslawiec which is a subset of what I have on my own Boleslawiec page.

One of the cool features of the site is that you can create Maps of where you hvae been in the world.  I have created my maps below.  -->

  • States in the USA
  • Places in the World
Article.ArticleDescription: I found World66.com today, a wiki travel web site

Article.ArticleBody:
New Orleans - February 11, 1995

 

Family and friends joined the happy couple as the vows were exchanged at the beautiful St. Mary's Church in the "Uptown" section of New Orleans. After the ceremonies, the newlyweds kicked off a day of celebration at the Ladies Opera Guild Home in the beautiful "Garden District ". The food was prepared with excellence by Food Art of New Orleans.

The music was provided by a jazz combo that sounded a lot like Chet Baker. The couple danced to many songs, most special was their song "My Funny Valentine". Mark was heard saying, "This is the best thing that has ever happened to me." After the reception, the entire wedding party headed for the French Quarter to continue the celebration of this union.

This is the Frogsfolly Bananas Foster as perfected on my back yard grill. It is really surprising how easy this dish is to prepare. It is also very rich and quite a show stopper. I like to prepare it on my backyard burner at night to highlight the flame.

Ingredients

  • 1 stick butter
  • 1/2 cup brown sugar
  • 4 bananas peeled and halved, cut lengthwise
  • 1/4 cup dark rum
  • 1/4 cup Triple Sec

Melt butter in a large skillet. Add brown sugar and stir together. Add the bananas and cook until caramelized over medium-high heat. Pour in the rum and liqueur and catch a flame off of the gas stove or a BBQ lighter. Let flame die down. Serve over vanilla ice cream.
Article.ArticleDescription: Here is the Frogsfolly version of this famous New Orleans dessert which was invented by Ella Brennan, Chef Owner of the legendary New Orleans restaurant ‚ÄúThe Commander‚Äôs Palace.‚Äù

Article.ArticleBody:
Indegrediants

2 pounds boneless skinless chicken in strips
1 tablespoon olive oil

1 cup chopped onion
2 large garlic cloves, chopped
3 Vine Ripe Tomatoes
3/4 cup Kalamata olives or other brine-cured black olives, pitted, sliced
1/2 cup Garlic Wine Vinigar
2 teaspoons dried

2/3 cup crumbled feta cheese

Preparation

Sprinkle chicken with salt and pepper. Heat oil in large skillet over medium-high heat. Add chicken and sauté until brown, about 4 minutes per side. Transfer chicken to plate. Pour off all but 2 tablespoons drippings from skillet.

Add onion to drippings in skillet. Sauté over medium heat 3 minutes. Add garlic and stir until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add tomatoes with juices, olives, wine and oregano. Return chicken and any accumulated juices to sauce; bring to boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover and simmer until chicken is tender and cooked through, about 25 minutes.

Transfer chicken and sauce to platter. Sprinkle with feta cheese and serve.
Article.ArticleDescription: Chicken and Olives is a basic dish that I have been working on. I don't have it perfect just yet, let me know if you have any ideas.

Article.ArticleBody:
• 8 ounce Bread
    (stale bread is much easier to work with; bread should be coarse, country-style, not too dense: look for lots of holes within the bread, that kind will make a light crouton)
  • 1/4 pound, butter (1/2 cup)
  • 1/4 cup, olive oil
  • 4 cloves, garlic - peeled and minced
  • 6 shallots - peeled and minced
    (substitute 1/4 of one large sweet onion)
  • salt and pepper to taste
  • 4 teaspoons, dried thyme
  • 3 tablespoons, lemon juice
  • 1/3 cup, fresh chopped parsley
Preheat oven to 275 degrees.
Trim crusts from bread, and cut into one-inch cubes. Melt the butter in a deep skillet, along with the olive oil, and sauté` the garlic and shallots over low heat, until soft but not brown. Add salt, pepper and thyme to garlic and shallots as the mixture is sautéed. Then add lemon juice and chopped parsley, and blend well, continuing to cook briefly to incorporate flavors.

Remove the mixture from heat, and toss the bread cubes quickly and thoroughly in the mixture to coat the cubes evenly. Spread the bread cubes on a sheet pan, and bake at 275 degrees, tossing occasionally, until very crisp and lightly toasted. Drain finished bread cubes on a paper towel

Ginger Chicken

Preparation 45 mins plus at least 1 hour marinating time for Chicken and Pineapple

Serves: 6

Ingredients

  • 2lbs boneless skinless chicken (cut in large cubes)
  • 1 medium onion (chopped)
  • 1 Red Pepper (chopped)
  • Salt and freshly ground ground black pepper
  • Thinly sliced red pepper
  • Mangetout
  • Broccli
  • Carrots
  • Cubed Pineapple (drained if canned)

 

For the marinade:

  • 4 oz fresh root ginger, peeled, grated and squeezed for the juice
  • 2 tbsp finely chopped garlic
  • 1 cup Orange Juice
  • 1 cup soy sauce
  • 1 cup dry white wine

 

Directions

Prepare the marinade by mixing all ingredients in a container big enough to the chicken,pineapple and marinade. Marinate the pineapple and chicken for 1-4 hours.

Scalloped Potatoes with Ham

  • 1 pound fully cooked ham slice, 1/2-inch thick
  • 5 cup thinly sliced potatoes
  • 1 can (10 1/2 ounces) cream of mushroom soup or cream of celery soup
  • 1/4 cup milk
  • 1/2 cup chopped onion
  • 1/4 cup chopped green bell pepper
  • dash pepper
  • 2 tablespoons butter
  • 1 cup shredded Cheddar cheese, optional

Directions for scalloped potatoes
Cut ham in bite-size cubes. Place half of the potatoes in a greased, shallow, 2-quart baking dish. Cover with ham pieces. Top with remaining potatoes. Combine soup with milk, onion, green bell pepper, and ground black pepper; pour over potatoes. Dot with butter. Cover with foil and bake at 3500 for 1 hour. Remove covering; bake 30 to 45 minutes longer, or until potatoes are done. If desired, sprinkle shredded Cheddar cheese over the top of scalloped potatoes the last 15 minutes of baking time.
Scalloped potatoes serves 6.

Potatoes with Ham au Gratin

  • 4 cups diced potatoes
  • 2 cups chopped green onions
  • 5 tablespoons butter
  • 5 tablespoons all-purpose flour
  • 2 1/2 cups milk
  • 2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce
  • 1/2 teaspoon prepared yellow mustard
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • 1/2 teaspoon pepper
  • 1/4 teaspoon paprika
  • 4 pimiento, diced
  • 2 cups cheddar cheese, grated
  • 2 cups ham, cubed 1/2"
  • 1/2 cup plain bread crumbs
  • 4 tablespoons butter

In a saucepan cook potatoes and onions together in lightly salted water until tender, 12 - 15 minutes. Drain. To make white sauce melt butter in a medium saucepan. Add flour stirring until blended. Cook and slowly stir in milk. Add Worcestershire, mustard, salt, pepper, paprika and pimiento. Stir until thick. Place 1/2 of the cooked potatoes and onions in a large buttered 3-quart baking dish. Cover potatoes with 1/2 of the cheese. Spread all the ham on the cheese. Cover with remaining potatoes.

Pour white sauce over all. Sprinkle remaining cheese on top. Place bread crumbs on cheese. Dot top with butter. Bake in preheated 350 degree F oven until top is melted, about 10 minutes.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

Heath Bar Cake

A party favorite

Makes one cake


Prep Time:
Cook Time:
Ready in:

 

Ingredients Box White Cake Mix 4 oz Box Instant Chocolate Pudding 2 Cups Water 3 Egg Whites

Frosting: 1 teaspoon vanilla 1 cup powder sugar < cup margarine melted & slightly cooled 8 oz cool whip

 

Directions  Mix ingredients together and pour into a 9x13-baking pan.  Bake at 350 degrees for 40 minutes.  Test with toothpick for doneness.  Let cake cool before frosting.  

Enjoy!
Article.ArticleDescription: A recipie for a Heath Bar Cake, party favorite that is easy to make.

Article.ArticleBody:
Jambalaya

"Cajun Classic"

Makes 6 to 8 servings


Prep Time:
Cook Time:
Ready in:

 

 

Ingredients 

4 Chicken Breasts

1 onion

1 stalk of celery

1.5 pounds of sausage (1/2 pound hot, 1 pound regular chappalhill garlic or pork and venison at Kroger )

4 onions chopped

4 cloves of garlic minced

1 red pepper diced (can use yellow or orange as well) Add = poblano pepper for a little zest

2 cans hunts diced tomatoes (roasted garlic or red pepper spiced are good)

3 cooking spoons oil

3 cooking spoons flour

2 cups of rice

6 to 7 cups of stock

 

 

Directions  
 

Chop one onion and celery stalk in large pieces and boil with chicken breasts for 1 hour. This makes the stock for use later and prepares the chicken for the jambalaya. Chop 4 onions, red pepper, garlic and slice sausage and sauti. Prepare the roux in large stockpot. Roux: Heat 3 cooking spoons of oil until hot then add 3 cooking spoons of flour. Stir constantly until dark brown (the color of milk chocolate). Immediately add onions, garlic, and sausage. Stir and cook for 3 minutes. Add diced tomatoes and stir. Add chunked chicken and stir. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add 5 cups chicken stock from boiling chicken breasts. Stir and add 2 cups of rice. Cook for 30 minutes (or until all liquid is absorbed) on low to simmer stirring occasionally to avoid sticking. Take off heat and put into large dish. Wait 30 minutes before serving, better reheated.

Serves 8 to 10.
Article.ArticleDescription: Recipie for Jambalaya, a cajun favorite with Chicken and Sausage in a tomato and rice dish.

Article.ArticleBody:
Meatloaf

This is an easy tasty meatloaf.

Makes 6 to 8 servings


Prep Time: 20 Minutes
Cook Time: 1 Hour
Ready in: 1 Hour 30 Minutes
Ingredients (Loaf)
  • 2 cups of Bread Crumbs
  • 1 medium Onion (chopped)
  • 1 medium Red Pepper (chopped)
  • 2 Cloves Garlic (minced)
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 1/2 lbs Ground Veal (or pork)
  • 1 1/2 lbs Ground Beef (or lamb)
  • 2 Tablespoons Horseradish
  • 2 1/2 teaspoons salt
  • 1 teaspoon Dry Mustard
  • 1/4 cup Milk
  • 3/4 cup Ketchup
Ingredients (Sauce)
  • 3/4 cup Ketchup
  • 2 Tablespoons Brown Sugar
  • 2 Tablespoons Hot Mustard
  • 1 Tablespoon Dry Mustard
  • 1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce
Directions
  1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (~205 degrees C).
  2. Prepare bread crumbs, onions, and red pepper.
  3. In a large bowl, beat eggs slightly and mix in ground meat, bread crumbs, onions, and red peppers
  4. After mixture is well blended, ad horseradish, salt, dry mustard, milk and ketchup to bowl
  5. Lightly mix and shape into loaf
  6. Place loaf in a cooking dish (with space around loaf), indent the top of the loaf
  7. Mix all sauce ingredients together and coat the loaf. Use excess to fill the indentation in the top
  8. Bake in bottom rack of oven for 1 hour
Enjoy
Article.ArticleDescription: The meatloaf & recipe, an amerian classic, with a spicy mustard twist.

Article.ArticleBody:
Ingredients
Directions
  • 1 lb lean ground beef
  • 1 lb ground lamb
  • 2 eggs
  • 1 cup milk
  • ½ cup rolled oats
  • ½ cup chopped parsley
  • 1 cup minced onion
  • ½ cup red pepper, minced
  • juice of ½ lemon
  • grated zest of ½ orange
  • 1 cup pine nuts
  • 1 cup white raisins
  • 1 tsp ground allspice
  • 1 tsp dried thyme
  • l½ tsp salt
  • 1 tsp black pepper
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 3 TBS Worcestershire sauce
  • 2 TBS clarified butter
  1. Preheat oven to 425°
  2. In a bowl, combine ground beef, and lamb. In a separate bowl, beat eggs, Stir in the milk and oats. Pour into the meats. Mix thoroughly.
  3. Add all other ingredients except clarified butter. Mix well. (use your hands).
  4. Shape mixture into an oval loaf and place in a roasting pan. Drizzle with clarified butter and bake for 1 hour. Serve drizzled with sauce.
Yield: six to eight servings.

Sauce

Ingredients Directions
  • 2 TBS butter (or olive oil)
  • 1 cup finely chopped onions
  • ½ cup finely chopped green pepper
  • 1 bay leaf
  • 1 clove garlic, minced
  • Juice of 1 lemon
  • ½ cup white raisins
  • 1 tsp dried thyme
  • 1 tsp ground allspice
  • 4 cups canned tomatoes, with their juice (use Italian with basil)
  • 2 TBS tomato paste (optional)
  • 3 TBS chopped parsley
  1. In a skillet, heat butter (olive oil). Add onions, green pepper, and bay leaf and sauté until the onion is translucent and limp, about 5-10 minutes.
  2. Add the remaining ingredients, except tomato paste and parsley, breaking the tomatoes into small pieces as you add them. Simmer for 30 minutes, or until sauce begins to thicken.
  3. Add the tomatoes paste and stir well. Cook 15 minutes. Add the parsley, stir well. Serve over the Meat Loaf.
Yield: 4 cups.

Ginger Salmon

"This is a recipe I came upon while in Poland.  I was doing a lot of the cooking and wanted to do something different.   

I got some fresh ginger and salmon and it took off from there. "

Makes 2 to 4 servings


Prep Time: 20 Minutes
Cook Time: 1 Hour
Ready in: 1 Hour 30 Minutes

Ingredients

Salmon Filet

 Ingredients (Sauce)
  • Fresh Ginger (pickled ginger can be used in a pinch)
  • Sweet Chili Sauce (many varietes to choose from, can be found in Asian section)
  • Orange Juice
  • Fresh Citrus (Orange or Tangerine)
  • Soy Sauce
Directions
  1. Mince the ginger by chopping very fine
  2. Juice the citrus and finely chop the pulp
  3. In a small sause pan, add the Orange Juice, Ginger, Soy Sauce and pulp from the fresh citrus.  Add sweet chili sauce to taste. Bring to a low boil and let it reduce.  Be carefull not to allow the mixture to boil over.  As it reduces it will become thicker.  Tastes often and adjust as necessary by adding more juice or soy sauce.
  4. Place salmon filet skin down on a cooking sheet, Strain the pulp from the sauce and put a thin layer over the salmon, you may also add a little butter to the salmon.  Optional is to slice an orange or lemon and place the slices on top of the salmon
  5. Place salmon filet in oven at 325 for 30 mins
  6. Remove salmon filet, slice and then drizzle sauce over filet

Server with rice and steamed vegatables and a nice wine.

Enjoy

Article.ArticleBody:
Pork With Ginger

Preparation 25 mins plus at least 30 mins marinating

Serves: 4

Calories/Fat: 254 cals / 13g

Sodium/Added sugar: 1.2g / none

Directions

Marinade the pork steaks in a non-metallic bowl with the ginger juice, soy sauce and white wine for at least 30 mins.

Heat 1 tbsp of oil in a frying pan and stir-fry the onion/red pepper for 4-5 mins or until softened. Set aside.

Heat the remaining oil in the same frying pan and fry the pork steaks for 6 mins, turning occasionally. Add the marinade and fry for a further 1 min.

Remove the pork steaks and add back in the onions and red pepper, reduce until you have a nice thick sause

Create a bed of rice and place the pork steak in the middle.

Drizzle the sauce over and arround the pork steak

Serve with Fresh Orange pieces and green beens

Spicy Crawfish Etouffee

"Another Cajun Classic"

Makes 6 to 8 servings


Prep Time:
Cook Time:
Ready in:

 

 

Ingredients  

2 tablespoons reduced-fat margarine

1 1/2 cups finely chopped onions

1/2 cup finely chopped green bell pepper (I use red peppers)

1/2 cup finely chopped celery

1 teaspoon salt

1 1/4 teaspoons ground red pepper

1 teaspoon paprika

1/4 teaspoon ground oregano

1/8 teaspoon ground thyme

1/8 teaspoon dried basil leaves, crushed

1/2, 6 ounce can condensed tomato paste

1 1/2 cups seafood stock or water (I use clam liquor - you can buy in jar in grocery store)

1 pound crawfish tails, peeled and deveined (I use frozen tails you can buy at store)

1/4 cup finely chopped green onions

2 tablespoons very finely chopped fresh parsley

2 cups hot cooked rice

 

 

Directions  

In a medium saucepan over high heat, melt the margarine.  Add the onions, bell pepper and celery; sauti stirring occasionally for 10 minutes.  Add the salt, pepper, paprika, oregano, thyme, and basil leaves, and cook for 5 minutes, stirring often.

Dissolve the tomato paste in the stock and add to the sauce pan.

Simmer for 10 minutes.  Stir in the crawfish, green onions and parsley.  Reduce the heat; cover and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring often.  Remove from the heat and let stand, covered, for 5 minutes before serving.  Serve over hot rice.

Article.ArticleBody:
The phrase "when pigs fly" is an adynaton – a figure of speech so hyperbolic that it describes an impossibility. The implication of such a phrase is that the circumstances in question (the adynaton, and the circumstances to which the adynaton are being applied) will never occur.

The phrase is thought to come from an old Scottish proverb of the 16th century.

Pigs Can Fly is a unique puzzle game! Get the pig to the potion in 25 neat levels. But there is a fun twist - you need to use multiple cursors in order to beat each level. Give it a try!

Game Controls

Each colored potion resets the level and allows you to control a cursor. The pig can only be dragged with the pink cursor, and blue and green boxes can only be dragged with the blue and green cursors respectively. The objective is to get the pig to the potion so he can grow wings and fly away. In some levels, you are not even given a pink potion! The levels get more challenging so try to think it through first!
Article.ArticleSummary: Pigs Can Fly is a unique puzzle game! Get the pig to the potion in 25 neat levels. But there is a fun twist - you need to use multiple cursors in order to beat each level. Give it a try!

Article.ArticleBody:
In Greek mythology, Achilles (also Akhilleus or Achilleus; Ancient Greek: ·ºàœáŒπŒªŒªŒµœçœÇ) was a Greek hero of the Trojan War, the central character and the greatest warrior of Homer's Iliad, which takes for its theme the Wrath of Achilles.

Achilles also has the attributes of being the most handsome of the heroes assembled against Troy,[1] as well as the best.

Later legends (beginning with a poem by Statius in the first century AD) state that Achillies was invulnerable in all of his body except for his heel. These legends state that Achilles was killed in battle by an arrow to the heel, and so an "Achilles' heel" has come to mean a person's principal weakness.

Article.ArticleBody:
Bubble Tanks Tower Defense by Hero Interactive, LLC
Evolve your towers for epic win.

Bubble Tanks Tower Defense takes Hero's popular series into new genres and beyond! With 7 enemy types, over 11 unique tower paths, tower merging allowing for mega towers and mega-mega towers (the size of 16 towers combined!), and 52 whopping game modes, we're pretty sure you'll have plenty to keep you busy until the release of Bubble Tanks Arenas. :) If that's not enough for you, just check the "FML" checkbox from level select and prepare to get your world rocked... er... blocked.


Publisher's Note:
"This has been a huge undertaking for Hero Interactive and we're proud to finally release the game. A special thanks goes out to our fans for all of your support!"

Article.ArticleBody:
What is Twitter?

Twitter the site is a micro-blogging social media web site.  Think of it like group texting with a limit of 140 characters.  What people do with twitter is varied. Some use it as a social bookmarking site, the post a short comment and a shortened URL, others use it as a way to update there community with a status of what they are doing.

Twitter search allows you to do a keyword search on all updates across the site.

Twitter the company is a privately funded start up with offices in the SoMA neighborhood of San Francisco, CA. Started as a side project in March of 2006, Twitter has grown into a real-time short messaging service that works over multiple networks and devices.

 

Kevin explains Twitter to Dave
Article.ArticleSummary: All about Twitter
